Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 11, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In March of 1892, three Black grocery store owners 
in Memphis, Tennessee, were murdered by a mob of white men. Lynchings like these were happening 
all over the American South, often without any subsequent legal 
investigation or consequences for the murderers. But this time, a young journalist and 
friend of the victims set out to expose the truth 
about these killings. Her reports would shock the nation and launch her career as an 
investigative journalist, civic leader, and civil rights advocate. Her name was Ida B. Wells. Ida Bell Wells was born into slavery 
in Holly Springs, Mississippi on July 16, 1862, several months before
the Emancipation Proclamation released her and her family. After losing both parents and a brother 
to yellow fever at the age of 16, she supported her five remaining siblings by working as a schoolteacher 
in Memphis, Tennessee. During this time, she began working as a journalist. Writing under the pen name “Iola,” by the early 1890s she gained 
a reputation as a clear voice against racial injustice and become co-owner and editor of the Memphis Free Speech 
and Headlight newspaper. She had no shortage of material: in the decades following the Civil War, Southern whites attempted to reassert 
their power by committing crimes against Black people including suppressing their votes, vandalizing their businesses, 
and even murdering them. After the murder of her friends, Wells launched an investigation 
into lynching. She analyzed specific cases through 
newspaper reports and police records, and interviewed people who had lost 
friends and family to lynch mobs. She risked her life 
to get this information. As a Black person investigating racially 
motivated murders, she enraged many of the same southern 
white men involved in lynchings. Her bravery paid off. Most whites had claimed and 
subsequently reported that lynchings were responses to criminal
acts by Black people. But that was not usually the case. Through her research, Wells showed that these murders 
were actually a deliberate, brutal tactic to control or punish 
black people who competed with whites. Her friends, for example, had been lynched when their grocery store became popular enough to divert business 
from a white competitor. Wells published her findings in 1892. In response, a white mob destroyed 
her newspaper presses. She was out of town when they struck, but they threatened to kill her 
if she ever returned to Memphis. So she traveled to New York, where that same year she re-published 
her research in a pamphlet titled Southern Horrors: Lynch Law 
in All Its Phases. In 1895, after settling in Chicago, she built on Southern Horrors in a longer 
piece called The Red Record. Her careful documentation of the horrors 
of lynching and impassioned public speeches 
drew international attention. Wells used her newfound fame 
to amplify her message. She traveled to Europe, where she rallied European outrage against
racial violence in the American South in hopes that the US government and public
would follow their example. Back in the US, she didn’t hesitate to confront powerful 
organizations, fighting the segregationist 
policies of the YMCA and leading a delegation 
to the White House to protest discriminatory 
workplace practices. She did all this while 
disenfranchised herself. Women didn’t win the right to vote 
until Wells was in her late 50s. And even then, the vote was primarily 
extended to white women only. Wells was a key player in the battle 
for voting inclusion, starting a Black women’s 
suffrage organization in Chicago. But in spite of her deep commitment 
to women’s rights, she clashed with white leaders 
of the movement. During a march for women’s 
suffrage in Washington D.C., she ignored the organizers’ attempt 
to placate Southern bigotry by placing Black women in the back, and marched up front alongside
the white women. She also chafed with other 
civil rights leaders, who saw her as a dangerous radical. She insisted on airing, in full detail, 
the atrocities taking place in the South, while others thought doing so would be 
counterproductive to negotiations with white politicians. Although she participated in the founding 
of the NAACP, she was soon sidelined 
from the organization. Wells’ unwillingness to compromise any 
aspect of her vision of justice shined a light on the weak points 
of the various rights movements, and ultimately made them stronger— but also made it difficult for her 
to find a place within them. She was ahead of her time, waging a tireless struggle 
for equality and justice decades before many had even begun 
to imagine it possible.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Southern whites attempted to reassert their power by committing crimes against Black people including:
Options: A. Suppressing the vote, B. Vandalizing businesses, C. Murder, D. All of the above
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Where was Ida B. Wells born into slavery in 1862? Options: A. Memphis, Tennessee, B. Holly Springs, Mississippi, C. Chicago, Illinois, D. New York City, New York Correct Option: B
Question 2: What was the title of Ida B. Wells' pamphlet on lynching published in 1892? Options: A. The Red Record, B. Southern Horrors: Lynch Law in All Its Phases, C. The Lynching Epidemic, D. Racial Violence in the American South Correct Option: B
Question 3: What event motivated Ida B. Wells to investigate lynching in the American South? Options: A. The murder of her friends, three Black grocery store owners in Memphis, Tennessee, B. The passage of the Emancipation Proclamation, C. The formation of the NAACP, D. A personal experience with racial violence Correct Option: A
Question 4: How did Ida B. Wells' findings on lynching challenge the common narrative of the time? Options: A. She found that lynchings were a response to criminal acts by Black people, B. She found that lynchings were a deliberate tactic to control or punish Black people who competed with whites, C. She found that lynchings were a result of economic competition between Black and white people, D. She found that lynchings were a form of social control used by the government Correct Option: B
Question 5: What approach did Ida B. Wells use to expose the truth about lynching in the American South? Options: A. Conducting interviews with local officials and business leaders, B. Analyzing newspaper reports and police records, and interviewing people who had lost friends and family to lynch mobs, C. Writing a series of opinion pieces condemning lynching, D. Conducting undercover investigations Correct Option: B
Question 6: How did Ida B. Wells' work address the intersectionality of racism and sexism in the American South during the late 19th century? Options: A. She focused primarily on racism and ignored sexism, B. She focused primarily on sexism and ignored racism, C. She addressed both issues separately, but not together, D. She addressed the intersectionality of both issues, highlighting how they were intertwined and mutually reinforcing Correct Option: D
Question 7: What was the relationship between lynching and racial control in the American South during the late 19th century, according to Ida B. Wells' research? Options: A. Lynching was a response to criminal acts by Black people, B. Lynching was a deliberate tactic to control or punish Black people who competed with whites, C. Lynching was a result of economic competition between Black and white people, D. Lynching was a form of social control used by the government Correct Option: B
Question 8: What was the impact of Ida B. Wells' research on lynching on the subsequent attention and action against racial violence? Options: A. Her research had no impact on the attention and action against racial violence, B. Her research led to a decrease in attention and action against racial violence, C. Her research led to increased international attention and action against racial violence, D. Her research led to a shift in focus from racial violence to economic issues Correct Option: C
Question 9: How did Ida B. Wells' work serve as a model for future generations of investigative journalists and activists? Options: A. Her work demonstrated the importance of objective reporting and avoiding activism, B. Her work showed that investigative journalism and activism can be effective in exposing injustices and bringing about change, C. Her work highlighted the need for journalists and activists to prioritize local issues over national or international ones, D. Her work emphasized the importance of using social media to raise awareness Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the most accurate evaluation of the impact of Ida B. Wells' work on the civil rights movement and the fight against racial violence? Options: A. Her work had a minimal impact on the civil rights movement and the fight against racial violence, B. Her work had a significant impact on the civil rights movement, but not on the fight against racial violence, C. Her work had a significant impact on the fight against racial violence, but not on the civil rights movement, D. Her work had a profound impact on both the civil rights movement and the fight against racial violence Correct Option: D


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is:

**Question 7: What was the relationship between lynching and racial control in the American South during the late 19th century, according to Ida B. Wells' research?**

Options: A. Lynching was a response to criminal acts by Black people, B. Lynching was a deliberate tactic to control or punish Black people who competed with whites, C. Lynching was a result of economic competition between Black and white people, D. Lynching was a form of social control used by the government

Correct Option: B

Although this question does not exactly match the ground truth MCQ, it is the closest match in terms of question intent, options, and content. The ground truth MCQ asks about the ways in which Southern whites attempted to reassert their power, while Question 7 asks about the relationship between lynching and racial control. However, both questions address the underlying theme of racial violence and control in the American South during the late 19th century.

The index of the most similar generated MCQ is: **7**

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 14, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
On December 12, 1904, 
Chief Lontulu laid 110 twigs in front of a foreign commission. Every twig represented a person 
in his village who died because of King Leopold’s horrific regime
in the Congo— all in the name of rubber. Chief Lontulu separated the twigs 
into four piles: tribal nobles, men, women, and children— then proceeded
to name the dead of one-by-one. His testimony joined hundreds of others
to help bring an end to one of the greatest atrocities 
in history. Beginning in the late 1800s, European countries participated in the
so-called “Scramble for Africa.” They colonized 90% of the continent, exploiting African resources 
and enriching their countries. Belgium had recently become
an independent kingdom. Its ruler, Leopold II, 
wanted to acquire what he called “a slice of this magnificent 
African cake.” Meanwhile, he read colonial explorer 
Henry Morton Stanley’s reports about traveling through Africa. Stanley emphasized 
the Congo basin’s majesty. So, in 1879, Leopold contracted him
to return to the Congo. There, Stanley deceived leaders 
into signing some 450 treaties allowing for land use. Leopold persuaded the US and European
powers to grant him ownership of the Congo, pledging to protect free trade 
in the region. And on May 29, 1885, a territory more than
80 times the size of Belgium and home to 20 million people was declared
his own private colony— by no one it actually belonged to. Leopold lost no time consolidating power 
in what he called the Congo Free State. He claimed land, raised an army, and forced many Congolese men
to complete unpaid labor. Things got even worse when, in 1887, a Scottish inventor redeveloped
the pneumatic tire, creating a massive international
market for rubber. The Congo had one of the world’s
largest supplies. Leopold seized the opportunity, requiring villages to meet 
ever-greater rubber quotas. Congolese men had to harvest
the material from wild vines. As supplies drained, they walked for days
to gather enough. Leopold’s army entered villages and held 
women and children hostage until the impossible quota was met. Soldiers sexually violated women 
and deprived children of food and water. Congolese people rebelled— they refused to cooperate, 
fought Leopold’s soldiers, hid in the forests, 
and destroyed rubber vines. Leopold’s army responded to resistance 
or failure to meet quotas with unflinching torture and executions. Because guns and ammunition
were expensive, officers ordered soldiers to prove they 
used their bullets in the line of duty by removing a hand from anyone 
they killed. However, many soldiers hunted 
using their guns. To avoid harsh penalties and account 
for lost bullets, they cut off living people’s hands. They also used this practice
as punishment. If rubber quotas weren’t met, soldiers would sever people’s hands
and bring them to their commanders instead of rubber. The regime dramatically upended
daily life and agriculture, causing widespread starvation and disease. Meanwhile, King Leopold built monuments 
and private estates with the wealth he extracted. Soon, people brought international
attention to the horrific abuses of Leopold’s Congo Free State. In 1890, American journalist 
George Washington Williams accused King Leopold of “deceit, fraud, 
robberies, arson, murder, slave-raiding,
and [a] general policy of cruelty.” In 1903, Diplomat Roger Casement 
wrote a report that corroborated the nature and scale of the atrocities. It was published the following year. In response, Leopold appointed his own 
commission to investigate the accusations. They heard numerous witness statements 
in the Congo— Chief Lontulu’s included. The report only confirmed the worst. Facing pressure, Leopold relinquished 
control of the Congo to the Belgian government in 1908. But this did not mean justice. The Belgian state awarded Leopold
50 million francs “in testimony for his great sacrifice 
in favor of the Congo.” He died the following year. Crowds booed his funeral procession. For more than 50 years following,
the Congo remained a Belgian colony, until declaring independence in 1960. That year, the Congo elected its first
prime minister, Patrice Lumumba. But months later, he was unseated 
in a US and Belgium backed coup. In early 1961, Lumumba was assassinated 
under Belgian supervision. The coup launched the country 
into a decades-long dictatorship. Around 10 million Congolese people 
are thought to have died during Leopold’s occupation and looting 
of the Congo. Despite this devastation, calls 
for reparations have gone unanswered. To this day, throughout Belgium can be 
found the monuments King Leopold built on a foundation of inconceivable cruelty.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which of the following natural resources was primarily exploited by King Leopold’s colonization of the Congo?
Options: A. Gold, B. Petroleum, C. Rubber, D. Agricultural products
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the main reason behind King Leopold's interest in acquiring the Congo in the late 1800s? Options: A. To spread Christianity and European culture, B. To exploit the Congo's natural resources, particularly rubber, C. To establish a strategic military base in Africa, D. To promote free trade in the region Correct Option: B
Question 2: How did King Leopold's regime affect the daily lives of Congolese people? Options: A. It brought economic prosperity and improved living conditions, B. It had a minimal impact on their daily lives, C. It led to widespread starvation, disease, and human rights abuses, D. It promoted cultural exchange and understanding between Europeans and Africans Correct Option: C
Question 3: What was the significance of Chief Lontulu's testimony in 1904? Options: A. It marked the beginning of King Leopold's regime in the Congo, B. It was a turning point in the international campaign to expose the atrocities in the Congo, C. It led to the immediate arrest and prosecution of King Leopold, D. It was a minor incident with no significant impact Correct Option: B
Question 4: What was the outcome of King Leopold's investigation into the accusations of atrocities in the Congo? Options: A. The report found no evidence of human rights abuses, B. The report confirmed the worst atrocities, leading to Leopold's relinquishing control of the Congo, C. The report was inconclusive, and no further action was taken, D. The report was never published, and the atrocities continued Correct Option: B
Question 5: What was the response of the Belgian government to King Leopold's relinquishing control of the Congo in 1908? Options: A. They prosecuted King Leopold for his crimes, B. They awarded King Leopold 50 million francs for his "great sacrifice", C. They established a new, independent government in the Congo, D. They continued to support King Leopold's regime Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 1. 

Although the question phrasing is different, the intent and content of Question 1 align with the ground truth MCQ. Both questions focus on the primary reason or resource behind King Leopold's colonization of the Congo. The correct option in Question 1 (B. To exploit the Congo's natural resources, particularly rubber) directly corresponds to the correct option in the ground truth MCQ (C. Rubber).

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 1.

Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 14, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
On December 12, 1904,

in his village who died because of King Leopold’s horrific regime
in the Congo— all in the name of rubber. Chief Lontulu separated the twigs

to help bring an end to one of the greatest atrocities 
in history. Beginning in the late 1800s, European countries participated in the

and enriching their countries. Belgium had recently become
an independent kingdom. Its ruler, Leopold II, 
wanted to acquire what he called “a slice of this magnificent 
African cake.” Meanwhile, he read colonial explorer 
Henry Morton Stanley’s reports about traveling through Africa. Stanley emphasized 
the Congo basin’s majesty. So, in 1879, Leopold contracted him
to return to the Congo. There, Stanley deceived leaders 
into signing some 450 treaties allowing for land use. Leopold persuaded the US and European
powers to grant him ownership of the Congo, pledging to protect free trade 
in the region. And on May 29, 1885, a territory more than

in what he called the Congo Free State. He claimed land, raised an army, and forced many Congolese men
to complete unpaid labor. Things got even worse when, in 1887, a Scottish inventor redeveloped
the pneumatic tire, creating a massive international
market for rubber. The Congo had one of the world’s
largest supplies. Leopold seized the opportunity, requiring villages to meet 
ever-greater rubber quotas. Congolese men had to harvest
the material from wild vines. As supplies drained, they walked for days
to gather enough. Leopold’s army entered villages and held 
women and children hostage until the impossible quota was met. Soldiers sexually violated women 
and deprived children of food and water. Congolese people rebelled— they refused to cooperate, 
fought Leopold’s soldiers, hid in the forests, 
and destroyed rubber vines. Leopold’s army responded to resistance 
or failure to meet quotas with unflinching torture and executions. Because guns and ammunition
were expensive, officers ordered soldiers to prove they 
used their bullets in the line of duty by removing a hand from anyone 
they killed. However, many soldiers hunted 
using their guns. To avoid harsh penalties and account 
for lost bullets, they cut off living people’s hands. They also used this practice
as punishment. If rubber quotas weren’t met, soldiers would sever people’s hands
and bring them to their commanders instead of rubber. The regime dramatically upended
daily life and agriculture, causing widespread starvation and disease. Meanwhile, King Leopold built monuments 
and private estates with the wealth he extracted. Soon, people brought international
attention to the horrific abuses of Leopold’s Congo Free State. In 1890, American journalist 
George Washington Williams accused King Leopold of “deceit, fraud, 
robberies, arson, murder, slave-raiding,
and [a] general policy of cruelty.” In 1903, Diplomat Roger Casement 
wrote a report that corroborated the nature and scale of the atrocities. It was published the following year. In response, Leopold appointed his own 
commission to investigate the accusations. They heard numerous witness statements 
in the Congo— Chief Lontulu’s included. The report only confirmed the worst. Facing pressure, Leopold relinquished 
control of the Congo to the Belgian government in 1908. But this did not mean justice. The Belgian state awarded Leopold
50 million francs “in testimony for his great sacrifice 
in favor of the Congo.” He died the following year. Crowds booed his funeral procession. For more than 50 years following,
the Congo remained a Belgian colony, until declaring independence in 1960. That year, the Congo elected its first
prime minister, Patrice Lumumba. But months later, he was unseated 
in a US and Belgium backed coup. In early 1961, Lumumba was assassinated 
under Belgian supervision. The coup launched the country 
into a decades-long dictatorship. Around 10 million Congolese people 
are thought to have died during Leopold’s occupation and looting 
of the Congo. Despite this devastation, calls 
for reparations have gone unanswered. To this day, throughout Belgium can be 
found the monuments King Leopold built on a foundation of inconceivable cruelty.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: ___ was the (Democratic Republic of the Congo) République du Congo’s first elected prime minister
Options: A. Étienne Tshisekedi, B. Patrice Lumumba, C. Roger Casement, D. Évariste Kimba
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the main reason behind King Leopold's interest in acquiring the Congo in the late 1800s? Options: A. To spread Christianity and European culture, B. To exploit the Congo's natural resources, particularly rubber, C. To establish a strategic military base in Africa, D. To promote free trade in the region Correct Option: B
Question 2: How did King Leopold's regime affect the daily lives of Congolese people? Options: A. It brought economic prosperity and improved living conditions, B. It had a minimal impact on their daily lives, C. It led to widespread starvation, disease, and human rights abuses, D. It promoted cultural exchange and understanding between Europeans and Africans Correct Option: C
Question 3: What was the significance of Chief Lontulu's testimony in 1904? Options: A. It marked the beginning of King Leopold's regime in the Congo, B. It was a turning point in the international campaign to expose the atrocities in the Congo, C. It led to the immediate arrest and prosecution of King Leopold, D. It was a minor incident with no significant impact Correct Option: B
Question 4: What was the outcome of King Leopold's investigation into the accusations of atrocities in the Congo? Options: A. The report found no evidence of human rights abuses, B. The report confirmed the worst atrocities, leading to Leopold's relinquishing control of the Congo, C. The report was inconclusive, and no further action was taken, D. The report was never published, and the atrocities continued Correct Option: B
Question 5: What was the response of the Belgian government to King Leopold's relinquishing control of the Congo in 1908? Options: A. They prosecuted King Leopold for his crimes, B. They awarded King Leopold 50 million francs for his "great sacrifice", C. They established a new, independent government in the Congo, D. They continued to support King Leopold's regime Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:

However, if I had to choose the most similar generated MCQ based on the broader topic of the Congo's history, I would say that none of the generated MCQs are similar to the ground truth MCQ.

But if you want me to choose from the given options, I would say that Question 3 is the least dissimilar, as it also deals with a specific event in the Congo's history, but it is still quite different from the ground truth MCQ.

So, my answer would be: None of the generated MCQs match the ground truth MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 14, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
On December 12, 1904, 
Chief Lontulu laid 110 twigs in front of a foreign commission. Every twig represented a person 
in his village who died because of King Leopold’s horrific regime
in the Congo— all in the name of rubber. Chief Lontulu separated the twigs 
into four piles: tribal nobles, men, women, and children— then proceeded
to name the dead of one-by-one. His testimony joined hundreds of others
to help bring an end to one of the greatest atrocities 
in history. Beginning in the late 1800s, European countries participated in the
so-called “Scramble for Africa.” They colonized 90% of the continent, exploiting African resources 
and enriching their countries. Belgium had recently become
an independent kingdom. Its ruler, Leopold II, 
wanted to acquire what he called “a slice of this magnificent 
African cake.” Meanwhile, he read colonial explorer 
Henry Morton Stanley’s reports about traveling through Africa. Stanley emphasized 
the Congo basin’s majesty. So, in 1879, Leopold contracted him
to return to the Congo. There, Stanley deceived leaders 
into signing some 450 treaties allowing for land use. Leopold persuaded the US and European
powers to grant him ownership of the Congo, pledging to protect free trade 
in the region. And on May 29, 1885, a territory more than
80 times the size of Belgium and home to 20 million people was declared
his own private colony— by no one it actually belonged to. Leopold lost no time consolidating power 
in what he called the Congo Free State. He claimed land, raised an army, and forced many Congolese men
to complete unpaid labor. Things got even worse when, in 1887, a Scottish inventor redeveloped
the pneumatic tire, creating a massive international
market for rubber. The Congo had one of the world’s
largest supplies. Leopold seized the opportunity, requiring villages to meet 
ever-greater rubber quotas. Congolese men had to harvest
the material from wild vines. As supplies drained, they walked for days
to gather enough. Leopold’s army entered villages and held 
women and children hostage until the impossible quota was met. Soldiers sexually violated women 
and deprived children of food and water. Congolese people rebelled— they refused to cooperate, 
fought Leopold’s soldiers, hid in the forests, 
and destroyed rubber vines. Leopold’s army responded to resistance 
or failure to meet quotas with unflinching torture and executions. Because guns and ammunition
were expensive, officers ordered soldiers to prove they 
used their bullets in the line of duty by removing a hand from anyone 
they killed. However, many soldiers hunted 
using their guns. To avoid harsh penalties and account 
for lost bullets, they cut off living people’s hands. They also used this practice
as punishment. If rubber quotas weren’t met, soldiers would sever people’s hands
and bring them to their commanders instead of rubber. The regime dramatically upended
daily life and agriculture, causing widespread starvation and disease. Meanwhile, King Leopold built monuments 
and private estates with the wealth he extracted. Soon, people brought international
attention to the horrific abuses of Leopold’s Congo Free State. In 1890, American journalist 
George Washington Williams accused King Leopold of “deceit, fraud, 
robberies, arson, murder, slave-raiding,
and [a] general policy of cruelty.” In 1903, Diplomat Roger Casement 
wrote a report that corroborated the nature and scale of the atrocities. It was published the following year. In response, Leopold appointed his own 
commission to investigate the accusations. They heard numerous witness statements 
in the Congo— Chief Lontulu’s included. The report only confirmed the worst. Facing pressure, Leopold relinquished 
control of the Congo to the Belgian government in 1908. But this did not mean justice. The Belgian state awarded Leopold
50 million francs “in testimony for his great sacrifice 
in favor of the Congo.” He died the following year. Crowds booed his funeral procession. For more than 50 years following,
the Congo remained a Belgian colony, until declaring independence in 1960. That year, the Congo elected its first
prime minister, Patrice Lumumba. But months later, he was unseated 
in a US and Belgium backed coup. In early 1961, Lumumba was assassinated 
under Belgian supervision. The coup launched the country 
into a decades-long dictatorship. Around 10 million Congolese people 
are thought to have died during Leopold’s occupation and looting 
of the Congo. Despite this devastation, calls 
for reparations have gone unanswered. To this day, throughout Belgium can be 
found the monuments King Leopold built on a foundation of inconceivable cruelty.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: True or False: King Leopold was awarded 50 million francs for his colonial reign in the Congo
Options: A. True, B. False
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the main reason behind King Leopold's interest in acquiring the Congo in the late 1800s? Options: A. To spread Christianity and European culture, B. To exploit the Congo's natural resources, particularly rubber, C. To establish a strategic military base in Africa, D. To promote free trade in the region Correct Option: B
Question 2: How did King Leopold's regime affect the daily lives of Congolese people? Options: A. It brought economic prosperity and improved living conditions, B. It had a minimal impact on their daily lives, C. It led to widespread starvation, disease, and human rights abuses, D. It promoted cultural exchange and understanding between Europeans and Africans Correct Option: C
Question 3: What was the significance of Chief Lontulu's testimony in 1904? Options: A. It marked the beginning of King Leopold's regime in the Congo, B. It was a turning point in the international campaign to expose the atrocities in the Congo, C. It led to the immediate arrest and prosecution of King Leopold, D. It was a minor incident with no significant impact Correct Option: B
Question 4: What was the outcome of King Leopold's investigation into the accusations of atrocities in the Congo? Options: A. The report found no evidence of human rights abuses, B. The report confirmed the worst atrocities, leading to Leopold's relinquishing control of the Congo, C. The report was inconclusive, and no further action was taken, D. The report was never published, and the atrocities continued Correct Option: B
Question 5: What was the response of the Belgian government to King Leopold's relinquishing control of the Congo in 1908? Options: A. They prosecuted King Leopold for his crimes, B. They awarded King Leopold 50 million francs for his "great sacrifice", C. They established a new, independent government in the Congo, D. They continued to support King Leopold's regime Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

This is because both questions focus on the consequences of King Leopold's actions in the Congo, specifically the response of the Belgian government when he relinquished control in 1908. The correct options in both questions (A in the ground truth MCQ and B in Question 5) confirm that King Leopold was awarded 50 million francs, highlighting the similarity in question intent and content.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 15, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In early 1828, Sojourner Truth approached
the Grand Jury of Kingston, New York. She had no experience 
with the legal system, no money, and no power 
in the eyes of the court. Ignoring the jury’s scorn, Truth said she was there to fight for
custody of her five-year-old son Peter, who’d been illegally sold 
to an enslaver in Alabama. As the trial played out 
over the next several months, Truth raised funds, 
strategized with lawyers, and held her faith. Finally in the spring of 1828, 
Peter was returned to her care— but Truth’s work was far from over. She would dedicate 
the rest of her life to pursuing justice and spiritual understanding. Truth was born into slavery 
as Isabella Baumfree in the late 18th century
in Ulster County, New York. Although New York state had announced 
the abolition of slavery in 1799, the emancipation act was gradual. Those who were currently enslaved were forced to serve a period of 
indentured servitude until their mid-20s. Throughout this period, 
enslavers repeatedly sold Baumfree, tearing her from her loved ones. Often, she was explicitly prevented 
from pursuing new relationships. Eventually, she married an enslaved man 
named Thomas, with whom she had three children. She was desperate to keep 
her new family together— but the slow progress of abolition 
threatened this hope. Baumfree’s enslaver, John Dumont, 
had promised to free her by 1826. When he failed to keep his word, 
Baumfree fled for her safety. During the escape, she was only able 
to rescue her youngest daughter Sophia, while her other children 
remained in bondage. It would be two years before 
she regained custody of Peter. After that, she would wait 
another two years before she saw any of her other children. During this time, 
Baumfree found solace in her faith and became increasingly dedicated 
to religious reflection. After settling in Kingston, New York, she joined a Methodist community 
that shared her political views. She continued her practice of speaking 
aloud to God in private, and one night, her evening prayers
took on even more sacred significance. Baumfree claimed to hear the voice 
of God, telling her to leave Kingston, and share her holy message with others. Though she never learned to read or write, Baumfree became known 
as an electrifying orator, whose speeches drew on 
Biblical references, spiritual ideals, 
and her experience of slavery. Her sermons denounced the oppression 
of African Americans and women in general, and became prominent in campaigns 
for both abolition and women’s rights. In 1843, she renamed herself 
Sojourner Truth and embarked on a legendary 
speaking tour. Truth saw her journey 
as a mission from God. Her faith often led her 
to the nation’s most hostile regions, where she spoke to bigoted audiences 
as the only Black woman in the crowd. Truth was confident God would protect her, but some crowds responded 
to her bravery with violence. During one of her sermons, a mob of white men threatened to set 
fire to the tent where she was speaking. In her memoir, Truth recalled steeling 
herself to confront them: “Have I not faith enough to go out 
and quell that mob… I felt as if I had three hearts! And that they were so large, 
my body could hardly hold them!” She placated the men with song and prayer,
until they had no desire to harm her. Truth’s speeches impacted thousands of
people in communities across the nation, but her activism went far beyond
public speaking. During the Civil War, she became involved
with the Union Army, recruiting soldiers and organizing 
supplies for Black troops. Her work was so well regarded that 
she was invited to meet President Lincoln. She took the occasion to argue 
that all formerly enslaved people should be granted land by the government. Truth continued to travel 
and speak well into her 80s. Until her death in 1883, 
she remained an outspoken critic who fought for her right to be heard 
in a hostile world. As Truth once said, “I feel safe even
in the midst of my enemies; for the truth is powerful 
and will prevail."

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What was Sojourner Truth’s name at birth?
Options: A. Sally Turner, B. Isabella Baumfree, C. Harriet Douglass, D. Isabel Lewis
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Where was Sojourner Truth born? Options: A. Ulster County, New York, B. Kingston, New York, C. New York City, New York, D. Albany, New York Correct Option: A
Question 2: In what year did Sojourner Truth regain custody of her son Peter? Options: A. 1825, B. 1826, C. 1828, D. 1829 Correct Option: C
Question 3: What played a significant role in Sojourner Truth's life, providing solace and guiding her actions? Options: A. Her relationships with her family members, B. Her faith, C. Her experiences as an enslaved person, D. Her involvement in the Civil War Correct Option: B
Question 4: What informed Sojourner Truth's advocacy for abolition and women's rights? Options: A. Her experiences as a woman and a soldier, B. Her experiences as an enslaved person and a woman, C. Her experiences as a public speaker and activist, D. Her experiences as a member of the Methodist community Correct Option: B
Question 5: A contemporary social justice movement is seeking to amplify the voices of marginalized communities. What strategy, inspired by Sojourner Truth's example, could they use to achieve this goal? Options: A. Hosting fundraising events to support their cause, B. Organizing public speaking tours to share the stories of marginalized individuals, C. Creating social media campaigns to raise awareness about social justice issues, D. Recruiting volunteers to participate in community outreach programs Correct Option: B
Question 6: An individual is facing obstacles in their pursuit of social justice. What quality, demonstrated by Sojourner Truth, could they draw upon to overcome these challenges? Options: A. Perseverance and determination, B. Faith and personal values, C. Public speaking skills and charisma, D. Ability to recruit soldiers and organize supplies Correct Option: A
Question 7: How did Sojourner Truth's experiences as an enslaved person and a woman intersect and inform her advocacy? Options: A. Her experiences as an enslaved person informed her advocacy for women's rights, while her experiences as a woman informed her advocacy for abolition., B. Her experiences as an enslaved person and a woman intersected and informed her advocacy for both abolition and women's rights., C. Her experiences as an enslaved person and a woman had no impact on her advocacy for abolition and women's rights., D. Her experiences as an enslaved person informed her advocacy for abolition, while her experiences as a woman had no impact on her advocacy. Correct Option: B
Question 8: What role did faith play in Sojourner Truth's life and actions? Options: A. Faith played a minor role in Truth's life, providing occasional comfort and guidance., B. Faith played a significant role in Truth's life, providing solace and guiding her actions., C. Faith played no role in Truth's life and actions., D. Faith played a contradictory role in Truth's life, sometimes providing comfort and sometimes causing conflict. Correct Option: B
Question 9: How might Sojourner Truth's story be combined with other narratives of social justice and activism to create a more comprehensive understanding of the struggles and triumphs of marginalized communities? Options: A. By comparing and contrasting the experiences of different social justice movements, B. By examining the historical context of Truth's work and its impact on contemporary social justice movements, C. By creating a comprehensive timeline of social justice movements throughout history, D. By highlighting the unique challenges and triumphs of individual social justice activists Correct Option: A
Question 10: In what ways can Sojourner Truth's example of using faith and personal values to guide action be applied to contemporary social justice movements? Options: A. By encouraging individuals to separate their personal values from their social justice work, B. By promoting the use of faith and personal values as a guiding force in social justice activism, C. By ignoring the role of faith and personal values in social justice movements, D. By creating a secular approach to social justice activism Correct Option: B
Question 11: What judgment can be made about the significance of Sojourner Truth's work in the context of the broader social and historical landscape of the time? Options: A. Truth's work was insignificant and had little impact on the social and historical landscape of the time., B. Truth's work was moderately significant and had some impact on the social and historical landscape of the time., C. Truth's work was highly significant and had a profound impact on the social and historical landscape of the time., D. Truth's work was contradictory and had both positive and negative impacts on the social and historical landscape of the time. Correct Option: C
Question 12: How might Sojourner Truth's legacy be evaluated in terms of its ongoing impact on social justice movements and activism today? Options: A. Truth's legacy has had a lasting and profound impact on social justice movements and activism today., B. Truth's legacy has had a moderate impact on social justice movements and activism today., C. Truth's legacy has had little to no impact on social justice movements and activism today., D. Truth's legacy has had a negative impact on social justice movements and activism today. Correct Option: A


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that none of the generated MCQs exactly match the ground truth MCQ. However, I can suggest a generated MCQ that is somewhat related to the ground truth MCQ.

The ground truth MCQ asks about Sojourner Truth's name at birth, while the generated MCQs ask about various aspects of her life, such as her birthplace, experiences, and advocacy.

If I had to choose a generated MCQ that is somewhat related to the ground truth MCQ, I would suggest Question 1: "Where was Sojourner Truth born?" This question is related to Sojourner Truth's early life, but it does not ask about her name at birth.

However, I must emphasize that none of the generated MCQs are a good match for the ground truth MCQ. A more suitable generated MCQ would be one that asks about Sojourner Truth's name at birth, which is not present in the provided list.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 1 (with the caveat that it's not a good match)

to her bravery with violence. During one of her sermons, a mob of white men threatened to set

she was invited to meet President Lincoln. She took the occasion to argue

she remained an outspoken critic who fought for her right to be heard 
in a hostile world. As Truth once said, “I feel safe even
in the midst of my enemies; for the truth is powerful 
and will prevail."

Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Although Question 1 does not exactly match the ground truth MCQ, it is the most similar in terms of question intent, options, and content. Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 15, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In early 1828, Sojourner Truth approached
the Grand Jury of Kingston, New York. She had no experience 
with the legal system, no money, and no power 
in the eyes of the court. Ignoring the jury’s scorn, Truth said she was there to fight for
custody of her five-year-old son Peter, who’d been illegally sold 
to an enslaver in Alabama. As the trial played out 
over the next several months, Truth raised funds, 
strategized with lawyers, and held her faith. Finally in the spring of 1828, 
Peter was returned to her care— but Truth’s work was far from over. She would dedicate 
the rest of her life to pursuing justice and spiritual understanding. Truth was born into slavery 
as Isabella Baumfree in the late 18th century
in Ulster County, New York. Although New York state had announced 
the abolition of slavery in 1799, the emancipation act was gradual. Those who were currently enslaved were forced to serve a period of 
indentured servitude until their mid-20s. Throughout this period, 
enslavers repeatedly sold Baumfree, tearing her from her loved ones. Often, she was explicitly prevented 
from pursuing new relationships. Eventually, she married an enslaved man 
named Thomas, with whom she had three children. She was desperate to keep 
her new family together— but the slow progress of abolition 
threatened this hope. Baumfree’s enslaver, John Dumont, 
had promised to free her by 1826. When he failed to keep his word, 
Baumfree fled for her safety. During the escape, she was only able 
to rescue her youngest daughter Sophia, while her other children 
remained in bondage. It would be two years before 
she regained custody of Peter. After that, she would wait 
another two years before she saw any of her other children. During this time, 
Baumfree found solace in her faith and became increasingly dedicated 
to religious reflection. After settling in Kingston, New York, she joined a Methodist community 
that shared her political views. She continued her practice of speaking 
aloud to God in private, and one night, her evening prayers
took on even more sacred significance. Baumfree claimed to hear the voice 
of God, telling her to leave Kingston, and share her holy message with others. Though she never learned to read or write, Baumfree became known 
as an electrifying orator, whose speeches drew on 
Biblical references, spiritual ideals, 
and her experience of slavery. Her sermons denounced the oppression 
of African Americans and women in general, and became prominent in campaigns 
for both abolition and women’s rights. In 1843, she renamed herself 
Sojourner Truth and embarked on a legendary 
speaking tour. Truth saw her journey 
as a mission from God. Her faith often led her 
to the nation’s most hostile regions, where she spoke to bigoted audiences 
as the only Black woman in the crowd. Truth was confident God would protect her, but some crowds responded 
to her bravery with violence. During one of her sermons, a mob of white men threatened to set 
fire to the tent where she was speaking. In her memoir, Truth recalled steeling 
herself to confront them: “Have I not faith enough to go out 
and quell that mob… I felt as if I had three hearts! And that they were so large, 
my body could hardly hold them!” She placated the men with song and prayer,
until they had no desire to harm her. Truth’s speeches impacted thousands of
people in communities across the nation, but her activism went far beyond
public speaking. During the Civil War, she became involved
with the Union Army, recruiting soldiers and organizing 
supplies for Black troops. Her work was so well regarded that 
she was invited to meet President Lincoln. She took the occasion to argue 
that all formerly enslaved people should be granted land by the government. Truth continued to travel 
and speak well into her 80s. Until her death in 1883, 
she remained an outspoken critic who fought for her right to be heard 
in a hostile world. As Truth once said, “I feel safe even
in the midst of my enemies; for the truth is powerful 
and will prevail."

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Many people know of Truth for her activism, but she was also a wife and mother of how many children?
Options: A. 2, B. 3, C. 4, D. 5
Correct Option: B

Question 2: In what year did Sojourner Truth regain custody of her son Peter? Options: A. 1825, B. 1826, C. 1828, D. 1829 Correct Option: C
Question 3: What played a significant role in Sojourner Truth's life, providing solace and guiding her actions? Options: A. Her relationships with her family members, B. Her faith, C. Her experiences as an enslaved person, D. Her involvement in the Civil War Correct Option: B
Question 4: What informed Sojourner Truth's advocacy for abolition and women's rights? Options: A. Her experiences as a woman and a soldier, B. Her experiences as an enslaved person and a woman, C. Her experiences as a public speaker and activist, D. Her experiences as a member of the Methodist community Correct Option: B
Question 5: A contemporary social justice movement is seeking to amplify the voices of marginalized communities. What strategy, inspired by Sojourner Truth's example, could they use to achieve this goal? Options: A. Hosting fundraising events to support their cause, B. Organizing public speaking tours to share the stories of marginalized individuals, C. Creating social media campaigns to raise awareness about social justice issues, D. Recruiting volunteers to participate in community outreach programs Correct Option: B
Question 6: An individual is facing obstacles in their pursuit of social justice. What quality, demonstrated by Sojourner Truth, could they draw upon to overcome these challenges? Options: A. Perseverance and determination, B. Faith and personal values, C. Public speaking skills and charisma, D. Ability to recruit soldiers and organize supplies Correct Option: A
Question 7: How did Sojourner Truth's experiences as an enslaved person and a woman intersect and inform her advocacy? Options: A. Her experiences as an enslaved person informed her advocacy for women's rights, while her experiences as a woman informed her advocacy for abolition., B. Her experiences as an enslaved person and a woman intersected and informed her advocacy for both abolition and women's rights., C. Her experiences as an enslaved person and a woman had no impact on her advocacy for abolition and women's rights., D. Her experiences as an enslaved person informed her advocacy for abolition, while her experiences as a woman had no impact on her advocacy. Correct Option: B
Question 8: What role did faith play in Sojourner Truth's life and actions? Options: A. Faith played a minor role in Truth's life, providing occasional comfort and guidance., B. Faith played a significant role in Truth's life, providing solace and guiding her actions., C. Faith played no role in Truth's life and actions., D. Faith played a contradictory role in Truth's life, sometimes providing comfort and sometimes causing conflict. Correct Option: B
Question 9: How might Sojourner Truth's story be combined with other narratives of social justice and activism to create a more comprehensive understanding of the struggles and triumphs of marginalized communities? Options: A. By comparing and contrasting the experiences of different social justice movements, B. By examining the historical context of Truth's work and its impact on contemporary social justice movements, C. By creating a comprehensive timeline of social justice movements throughout history, D. By highlighting the unique challenges and triumphs of individual social justice activists Correct Option: A
Question 10: In what ways can Sojourner Truth's example of using faith and personal values to guide action be applied to contemporary social justice movements? Options: A. By encouraging individuals to separate their personal values from their social justice work, B. By promoting the use of faith and personal values as a guiding force in social justice activism, C. By ignoring the role of faith and personal values in social justice movements, D. By creating a secular approach to social justice activism Correct Option: B
Question 11: What judgment can be made about the significance of Sojourner Truth's work in the context of the broader social and historical landscape of the time? Options: A. Truth's work was insignificant and had little impact on the social and historical landscape of the time., B. Truth's work was moderately significant and had some impact on the social and historical landscape of the time., C. Truth's work was highly significant and had a profound impact on the social and historical landscape of the time., D. Truth's work was contradictory and had both positive and negative impacts on the social and historical landscape of the time. Correct Option: C
Question 12: How might Sojourner Truth's legacy be evaluated in terms of its ongoing impact on social justice movements and activism today? Options: A. Truth's legacy has had a lasting and profound impact on social justice movements and activism today., B. Truth's legacy has had a moderate impact on social justice movements and activism today., C. Truth's legacy has had little to no impact on social justice movements and activism today., D. Truth's legacy has had a negative impact on social justice movements and activism today. Correct Option: A

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 15, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In early 1828, Sojourner Truth approached
the Grand Jury of Kingston, New York. She had no experience 
with the legal system, no money, and no power 
in the eyes of the court. Ignoring the jury’s scorn, Truth said she was there to fight for
custody of her five-year-old son Peter, who’d been illegally sold 
to an enslaver in Alabama. As the trial played out 
over the next several months, Truth raised funds, 
strategized with lawyers, and held her faith. Finally in the spring of 1828, 
Peter was returned to her care— but Truth’s work was far from over. She would dedicate 
the rest of her life to pursuing justice and spiritual understanding. Truth was born into slavery 
as Isabella Baumfree in the late 18th century
in Ulster County, New York. Although New York state had announced 
the abolition of slavery in 1799, the emancipation act was gradual. Those who were currently enslaved were forced to serve a period of 
indentured servitude until their mid-20s. Throughout this period, 
enslavers repeatedly sold Baumfree, tearing her from her loved ones. Often, she was explicitly prevented 
from pursuing new relationships. Eventually, she married an enslaved man 
named Thomas, with whom she had three children. She was desperate to keep 
her new family together— but the slow progress of abolition 
threatened this hope. Baumfree’s enslaver, John Dumont, 
had promised to free her by 1826. When he failed to keep his word, 
Baumfree fled for her safety. During the escape, she was only able 
to rescue her youngest daughter Sophia, while her other children 
remained in bondage. It would be two years before 
she regained custody of Peter. After that, she would wait 
another two years before she saw any of her other children. During this time, 
Baumfree found solace in her faith and became increasingly dedicated 
to religious reflection. After settling in Kingston, New York, she joined a Methodist community 
that shared her political views. She continued her practice of speaking 
aloud to God in private, and one night, her evening prayers
took on even more sacred significance. Baumfree claimed to hear the voice 
of God, telling her to leave Kingston, and share her holy message with others. Though she never learned to read or write, Baumfree became known 
as an electrifying orator, whose speeches drew on 
Biblical references, spiritual ideals, 
and her experience of slavery. Her sermons denounced the oppression 
of African Americans and women in general, and became prominent in campaigns 
for both abolition and women’s rights. In 1843, she renamed herself 
Sojourner Truth and embarked on a legendary 
speaking tour. Truth saw her journey 
as a mission from God. Her faith often led her 
to the nation’s most hostile regions, where she spoke to bigoted audiences 
as the only Black woman in the crowd. Truth was confident God would protect her, but some crowds responded 
to her bravery with violence. During one of her sermons, a mob of white men threatened to set 
fire to the tent where she was speaking. In her memoir, Truth recalled steeling 
herself to confront them: “Have I not faith enough to go out 
and quell that mob… I felt as if I had three hearts! And that they were so large, 
my body could hardly hold them!” She placated the men with song and prayer,
until they had no desire to harm her. Truth’s speeches impacted thousands of
people in communities across the nation, but her activism went far beyond
public speaking. During the Civil War, she became involved
with the Union Army, recruiting soldiers and organizing 
supplies for Black troops. Her work was so well regarded that 
she was invited to meet President Lincoln. She took the occasion to argue 
that all formerly enslaved people should be granted land by the government. Truth continued to travel 
and speak well into her 80s. Until her death in 1883, 
she remained an outspoken critic who fought for her right to be heard 
in a hostile world. As Truth once said, “I feel safe even
in the midst of my enemies; for the truth is powerful 
and will prevail."

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: According to the lesson, what were the main causes Truth supported?
Options: A. Abolition and Women’s Rights, B. Freedom and Temperance, C. Religious Reform and Transcendentalism, D. Literacy and Education
Correct Option: A

**Transcript**:
In early 1828, Sojourner Truth approached
the Grand Jury of Kingston, New York. She had no experience 
with the legal system, no money, and no power 
in the eyes of the court. Ignoring the jury’s scorn, Truth said she was there to fight for
custody of her five-year-old son Peter, who’d been illegally sold 
to an enslaver in Alabama. As the trial played out 
over the next several months, Truth raised funds, 
strategized with lawyers, and held her faith. Finally in the spring of 1828, 
Peter was returned to her care— but Truth’s work was far from over. She would dedicate 
the rest of her life to pursuing justice and spiritual understanding. Truth was born into slavery 
as Isabella Baumfree in the late 18th century
in Ulster County, New York. Although New York state had announced 
the abolition of slavery in 1799, the emancipation act was gradual. Those who were currently enslaved were forced to serve a period of 
indentured servitude until their mid-20s. Throughout this period, 
enslavers repeatedly sold Baumfree, tearing her from her loved ones. Often, she was explicitly prevented 
from pursuing new relationships. Eventually, she married an enslaved man 
named Thomas, with whom she had three children. She was desperate to keep 
her new family together— but the slow progress of abolition 
threatened this hope. Baumfree’s enslaver, John Dumont, 
had promised to free her by 1826. When he failed to keep his word, 
Baumfree fled for her safety. During the escape, she was only able 
to rescue her youngest daughter Sophia, while her other children 
remained in bondage. It would be two years before 
she regained custody of Peter. After that, she would wait 
another two years before she saw any of her other children. During this time, 
Baumfree found solace in her faith and became increasingly dedicated 
to religious reflection. After settling in Kingston, New York, she joined a Methodist community 
that shared her political views. She continued her practice of speaking 
aloud to God in private, and one night, her evening prayers
took on even more sacred significance. Baumfree claimed to hear the voice 
of God, telling her to leave Kingston, and share her holy message with others. Though she never learned to read or write, Baumfree became known 
as an electrifying orator, whose speeches drew on 
Biblical references, spiritual ideals, 
and her experience of slavery. Her sermons denounced the oppression 
of African Americans and women in general, and became prominent in campaigns 
for both abolition and women’s rights. In 1843, she renamed herself 
Sojourner Truth and embarked on a legendary 
speaking tour. Truth saw her journey 
as a mission from God. Her faith often led her 
to the nation’s most hostile regions, where she spoke to bigoted audiences 
as the only Black woman in the crowd. Truth was confident God would protect her, but some crowds responded 
to her bravery with violence. During one of her sermons, a mob of white men threatened to set

she remained an outspoken critic who fought for her right to be heard 
in a hostile world. As Truth once said, “I feel safe even
in the midst of my enemies; for the truth is powerful 
and will prevail."

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 16, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:

time here is that Ted has an identity and you can actually say things here that have impacts around the world and sometimes when it comes through Ted it has meaning and power that it doesn't have when it doesn't and I mention that because I think identity is really important and we've had some fantastic presentations and I think what we've learned is that if you're a teacher your words can be meaningful but if you're a compassionate teacher they can be especially meaningful if you're a doctor you can do some good things but if you're a caring doctor you can do some other things so I want to talk about the power of identity and I didn't learn about this actually practicing law and doing the work that I do I I I actually learned about this from my grandmother I grew up in a house uh that was the traditional African-American home that was dominated by a matriarch and that matriarch was my grandmother that she was tough she was strong she was powerful uh she was the end of every argument in our family uh she was the beginning of a lot of arguments in our family uh she was the daughter of people who were actually enslaved her parents were born ens slavery in Virginia in the 1840s she was born in the 1880s and the experience of slavery very much shaped the way she saw the world and my mother my grandmother was tough but she was also loving when I would see her as a little boy she'd come up to me and she'd give me these hugs and she'd squeeze me so tight I could barely breathe and then she'd let me go and an hour or two later if I saw her she'd come over to me and she'd say Brian do you still feel me hugging you and if I said no she'd assault me again and if I'd say yes she'd leave me alone and then she just had this quality that you always wanted to be near her and the only challenge was that she had 10 children my mom was the youngest of her 10 kids and sometimes when I would go and spend time with her it'd be difficult to get her time and attention my cousins would be running around everywhere and I remember uh when I was about 8 or 9 years old waking up one morning going into the living room and all of my cousins were running around and my grandmother was sitting across the room staring at me and at first I thought we were playing a game and I would look at her and I'd smile but she was very serious and after about 15 or 20 minutes of this she got up
